<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Yet in no age can there have been a deeper gulf</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">between the artist and 
            <choice>
              <sic>socity</sic>
              <corr>society</corr>
            </choice>. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare">A young poet</rs> dedicates his</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sonnets to <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mrwh" key="Mr W. H.">Mr W. H.</rs> Not one of all those highly 
            <choice>
              <sic>eduvated</sic>
              <corr>educated</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nobles troubles to ask who is this patron? It is not a matter</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of interest in court circles. The plays are not discussed.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Lord 
            <choice>
              <sic>Southmapton</sic>
              <corr>Southampton</corr>
            </choice> and Lord Rutland, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rwhy" key="Whyte, Roland">Roland White</rs> wrote to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rsid" key="Sidney, Robert">Sir Robert Sidney</rs>, <quote source="#" rend="inline">pass away the time in London, merely in</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">going to plays 
            <choice>
              <sic>ev y</sic>
              <corr>every</corr>
            </choice> day"</quote> But the attraction of the stage</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">called forth no comment. The players lived too far from the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">court to stir curiosity. They were too much of servants,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">too much of minstrels, jugglers 
            <choice>
              <sic>nbear</sic>
              <corr>bear</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>laeders</sic>
              <corr>leaders</corr>
            </choice> to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">be a proper topic for gossip. Thus the early works of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Shakeepare</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice> make no ripple in the pool of 
            <choice>
              <sic>sielnce</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">No one protests that here is an upstart writer who is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for 
            <choice>
              <sic>throwin</sic>
              <corr>throwing</corr>
            </choice> society into the melting pot. The 
            <choice>
              <sic>grreat</sic>
              <corr>great</corr>
            </choice> might</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">be mocked--that was the 
            <choice>
              <sic>anicient</sic>
              <corr>ancient</corr>
            </choice> privilege of the court</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>jster</sic>
              <corr>jester</corr>
            </choice>; or some scene from history 
            <choice>
              <sic>re encated</sic>
              <corr>reenacted</corr>
            </choice>. But the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-stat" key="Stationer's Office, The">censor</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was quick to control irreverence. And in fact the dramatist</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wasn ot destroying society. The indignation that, after the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">first silent surprise, that <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-hibs" key="Ibsen, Henrik">Ibsen</rs> for example stirred in</l>
